title: Mathematics-Based Contextualized Learning Design for Adolescent Drug Prevention Education: Secondary Education Specialist Program

context.prior_knowledge: Basic knowledge of adolescent developmental psychology and health education, foundational statistics (mean/variance) and data interpretation skills, and introductory understanding of function graphs
context.additional_context: Strengthening the capability to design drug prevention education content linked to mathematics curriculum (probability, statistics, functions) - probability modeling using actual drug usage rate data, generating function graphs for drug impact simulations, etc.

learning_goals: Enhance the ability to explain statistical data and graph analysis tools on physiological and behavioral impacts of adolescent drug use, applying probability distributions, trendline analysis, and correlation coefficient calculations.

Acquire the ability to develop math-based prevention education materials by applying contextualized learning design models and probability/function concepts (quadratic function modeling, conditional probability scenario design).
Cultivate the ability to design effectiveness evaluation metrics for digital platform-based drug prevention education and apply equation modeling (linear regression analysis, optimization equations).
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
